posts.title: Memories of My Long Journey Home - A Memoir
posts.markdown:
*By —*

After clearing Customs in Tan Son Nhut Airport, I walked out onto Truong Son Road filled, as it was, with the fumes of the myriads of motorbikes and taxis packed together so tightly on the crowded street. I could also feel the humid air brushing my face.

The day of my arrival was an exceptionally busy day because it was Vietnamese New Year’s Eve. Bounteous amounts of red and yellow festive decorations crowded the streets. Shops lined up along the side of the road were selling traditional Vietnamese food; luckily I was starving so my mum let me buy one container of rice paper rolls. They were delicious!!

Looking around Saigon, I could feel the energy in the air. Non-stop talk was coming from all directions; there was no doubt that the colours played a huge impact on the vibrancy of this celebration. Marching bands were parading down the street, there were dragons dancing and prancing, writhing their way down the road, pictures of rabbits surrounded the area, lanterns shook above us and drums were beating.

Suddenly, a loud whistling noise caught everyone by surprise and a large firework exploded, I could see that this marked the beginning of the long night before Tet.

The money mum had given me was burning a hole in my pocket so I began looking around for food and souvenirs. Shops were selling fruits and meats; they even had a rabbit shop!!

The sweetly pungent smell of rotting fruit combined with the fumes of petrol and gas from roaring motorcycles and humid air to create an horrific stench which spread through the street. I didn’t manage to find a souvenir on that night but instead I found a secluded small shop just off the main street.

As I walked inside, there were people producing stunning artwork using eggshells and by the information on the walls, their parents were the victims of Agent Orange. What I noticed about this shop was that, compared to the loud, stinky, crowded shops of the marketplace, this shop was quiet and calm.

“A much better workplace,” I thought.

Walking around the little gallery, I felt sympathy for these people and their misfortunes and troubles they’d gone through. All their feelings were expressed in their art filled as it was with images of pain and suffering. Here I found a beautiful ceramic teapot which I decided to buy as my souvenir.

When I was told that we were going to go to Vietnam in 2011, I wasn’t really excited. I couldn’t get memories of horrific traffic, a city where rubbish cluttered the pavements, people loitering everywhere and their English so very difficult to understand, people who have no respect for outsiders.

However I eventually realised that despite the traffic, the tardiness of the people, the heat, the lack of English, most of the people were very nice to foreigners. Through my experiences, I was given the opportunity to reconnect with my Vietnamese culture and family. Every place I visited gave me a little hint about another aspect of my culture, my heritage, my family’s history.
posts.html:
By —

After clearing Customs in Tan Son Nhut Airport, I walked out onto Truong Son Road filled, as it was, with the fumes of the myriads of motorbikes and taxis packed together so tightly on the crowded street. I could also feel the humid air brushing my face.

The day of my arrival was an exceptionally busy day because it was Vietnamese New Year’s Eve. Bounteous amounts of red and yellow festive decorations crowded the streets. Shops lined up along the side of the road were selling traditional Vietnamese food; luckily I was starving so my mum let me buy one container of rice paper rolls. They were delicious!!

Looking around Saigon, I could feel the energy in the air. Non-stop talk was coming from all directions; there was no doubt that the colours played a huge impact on the vibrancy of this celebration. Marching bands were parading down the street, there were dragons dancing and prancing, writhing their way down the road, pictures of rabbits surrounded the area, lanterns shook above us and drums were beating.

I didn’t manage to find a souvenir on that night but instead I found a secluded small shop just off the main street.

As I walked inside, there were people producing stunning artwork using eggshells and by the information on the walls, their parents were the victims of Agent Orange. What I noticed about this shop was that, compared to the loud, stinky, crowded shops of the marketplace, this shop was quiet and calm.

“A much better workplace,” I thought.

When I was told that we were going to go to Vietnam in 2011, I wasn’t really excited. I couldn’t get memories of horrific traffic, a city where rubbish cluttered the pavements, people loitering everywhere and their English so very difficult to understand, people who have no respect for outsiders.

However I eventually realised that despite the traffic, the tardiness of the people, the heat, the lack of English, most of the people were very nice to foreigners. Through my experiences, I was given the opportunity to reconnect with my Vietnamese culture and family. Every place I visited gave me a little hint about another aspect of my culture, my heritage, my family’s history.

posts.title: Drip, drip, drip...
posts.markdown:
*By Aryan Verma —*

I came home late in the evening and found out that mum and dad were out of town for some party. Well, I was a bit afraid of being alone in the house since it was double storey with five large bedrooms. I turned on the radio and found myself a snack, and just then the music stopped and a deep voice came on and warned everyone living in the suburban area to lock all doors and close every window because there was a murderer on the loose. I quickly ran to every single door and window and locked them making sure the curtains were closed. But I didn’t worry too much because I had my faithful dog Spotless with me. We have been together since I was a little baby and both of us trust each other a lot.

I went to bed and Spotless curled up right under my bed. I dropped my hand down and Spotless licked it. Whenever he licks me I feel comfortable. I gave a sigh and fell asleep. After an hour or so I heard a faint noise from downstairs, but I ignored it. I let my hand fall on the side of the bed and he licked it. Not long after I fell asleep again I heard footsteps outside and I thought it might be mum and dad, so I stepped outside but saw no one. I went back inside and fell asleep with a lick on my hand. After a few hours I woke up again and heard a dripping sound. Probably it was from the kitchen tap. Fed up of the noises, I went downstairs and tightened the tap. I again went to sleep with a lick on my hand. Later I again woke up to a dripping sound and figured it must be from the bathroom. When I opened the door and turned on the lights I was frozen with fear.

From the ceiling of the bathroom, Spotless was hanging with blood dripping from his throat, and on the mirror there was a message: ‘Humans can lick too…’
posts.html:
By Aryan Verma —

I came home late in the evening and found out that mum and dad were out of town for some party. Well, I was a bit afraid of being alone in the house since it was double storey with five large bedrooms. I turned on the radio and found myself a snack, and just then the music stopped and a deep voice came on and warned everyone living in the suburban area to lock all doors and close every window because there was a murderer on the loose. I quickly ran to every single door and window and locked them making sure the curtains were closed. But I didn’t worry too much because I had my faithful dog Spotless with me. We have been together since I was a little baby and both of us trust each other a lot.

I went to bed and Spotless curled up right under my bed. I dropped my hand down and Spotless licked it. Whenever he licks me I feel comfortable. I gave a sigh and fell asleep. After an hour or so I heard a faint noise from downstairs, but I ignored it. I let my hand fall on the side of the bed and he licked it. Not long after I fell asleep again I heard footsteps outside and I thought it might be mum and dad, so I stepped outside but saw no one. I went back inside and fell asleep with a lick on my hand. After a few hours I woke up again and heard a dripping sound. Probably it was from the kitchen tap. Fed up of the noises, I went downstairs and tightened the tap. I again went to sleep with a lick on my hand. Later I again woke up to a dripping sound and figured it must be from the bathroom. When I opened the door and turned on the lights I was frozen with fear.

From the ceiling of the bathroom, Spotless was hanging with blood dripping from his throat, and on the mirror there was a message: ‘Humans can lick too…’

posts.title: Enter The Labyrinth
posts.markdown:
*By —*

Staring at this sandstone hall reminds me of that time I was looking through the pyramids in Egypt. Those creamy walls covered in gooey moss and hanging vines. Weird menacing plants popping out amongst those vines, with green and purple gas coming out of them. With beetles crawling around the tunnel and the cracks in the ceiling, I think the roof is going to fall in.

“Come on Sally, we’re waiting.”

I turn around and see Abe, the leader of this expedition. Abe and I have been friends ever since we met at University. At least I know him. Marco is so nervous he’s going to fall for one of the traps in this Labyrinth. And Peart seems okay, but I have this feeling about him.

“Coming,” I reply.

We walk through the dark entrance and see four paths. Abe lights four torches, one for each of us. This expedition is about finding the lost treasure of Arcani, but with so many places to go, it could be anywhere! I look among the walls; feel the roughness of the sandstones, smell the dead rats and beetles lingering around, see the ancient hieroglyphs among the walls. I just love it!

“Okay, guys, let’s start mapping where we’re going so we aren’t lost?”

“What if we split up so we can cover more area? That way we can find the centre of the maze quicker,” Pert suggested.

A minute later we were deciding which way we would go and where we would meet. I mean, this is one of the most dangerous labyrinths in the world. I take my piece of paper and split up from the rest of the group. I have been chosen to take the left path, so I take my torch and follow the path. I make little marks among these deserted corridors, that way I know how to come back.

After several metres of twists and turns I hear a creak. The walls are starting to move closer and close in on me! I see a hole in the roof. I run to below the hole, wait for just the right amount of time, then I scurry up the two walls and into the hole.

Easy. Too easy. ‘Swoosh’. I hear the noise of high pressure water. I turn around and see geysers in the walls with hot water shooting out of them. And when I say hot, I mean lava hot. The water is filling up the room quickly. The steam is clogging up the air. The labyrinth gods obviously know I’m asthmatic. I see a set of stairs at the other end of the tunnel. I climb up them to try and escape this boiling pot of soup.

*To Be Continued*

By —

After several metres of twists and turns I hear a creak. The walls are starting to move closer and close in on me! I see a hole in the roof. I run to below the hole, wait for just the right amount of time, then I scurry up the two walls and into the hole.

I climb up them to try and escape this boiling pot of soup.

posts.title: At Sea
posts.markdown:
*By Joshua Lam —*

I am held in its serrated jaw; realisation stabs me; I stare agape at the towering mountain. Icy water sloshes over my fur boot. The sun has barely risen and mist emits from my mouth. Wind billows at the near-paper sails as I tug on the strings – forming an eccentric dim-dappled pattern. Thirst dangles me over the edge of Death’s door. I am stuck in my own maelstrom of madness … or is this the reality? I am driven purely by hunger, I am desperate for the meat that I tasted – meat which now only exists as a fantasy. Sailing further away from life; rowing further away from life; but closer than ever to Death’s door. The towering mountain fills my vision, rocks jut out of the mountain front. Abruptly, a flash of grey enters my peripheral. I close my eye lids and open then cautiously under the surging sails. I manage a glimpse to the left, a glimpse to the right. I creep forward to the starboard – slowly … ever so slowly. My heart races faster; my mouth is agape; the hair on my back stands to attention. I am as helpless as an autumn leaf following the whirlpool of a drain.

 

I grasp the strings of the sails. I feel the harsh ropes cutting into my rough hands – the well-worked hands of a sailor. I slide myself to the floor of the deck and remain still … ever so still. I watch the billowing near-paper sails flapping to and fro. I am mesmerised. Hunger gnaws deep, deep in my stomach. Sheer terror overwhelms me as an ominous shadow fills the boat, the fragile, flimsy boat. I collapse onto the deck face down, knowing that I cannot fight the hunger, knowing that I cannot fight the terror. I give up! I take a final glace at the silhouette above and black out.
posts.html:
By Joshua Lam —

I am held in its serrated jaw; realisation stabs me; I stare agape at the towering mountain. Icy water sloshes over my fur boot. The sun has barely risen and mist emits from my mouth. Wind billows at the near-paper sails as I tug on the strings – forming an eccentric dim-dappled pattern. Thirst dangles me over the edge of Death’s door. I am stuck in my own maelstrom of madness … or is this the reality? I am driven purely by hunger, I am desperate for the meat that I tasted – meat which now only exists as a fantasy. Sailing further away from life; rowing further away from life; but closer than ever to Death’s door. The towering mountain fills my vision, rocks jut out of the mountain front. Abruptly, a flash of grey enters my peripheral. I close my eye lids and open then cautiously under the surging sails. I manage a glimpse to the left, a glimpse to the right. I creep forward to the starboard – slowly … ever so slowly. My heart races faster; my mouth is agape; the hair on my back stands to attention. I am as helpless as an autumn leaf following the whirlpool of a drain.

 

I grasp the strings of the sails. I feel the harsh ropes cutting into my rough hands – the well-worked hands of a sailor. I slide myself to the floor of the deck and remain still … ever so still. I watch the billowing near-paper sails flapping to and fro. I am mesmerised. Hunger gnaws deep, deep in my stomach. Sheer terror overwhelms me as an ominous shadow fills the boat, the fragile, flimsy boat. I collapse onto the deck face down, knowing that I cannot fight the hunger, knowing that I cannot fight the terror. I give up! I take a final glace at the silhouette above and black out.

posts.title: About
posts.markdown:
It’s easy to get too used to being a student.

At school, we’re students of our teachers. At home, we’re students of our parents. In life, we’re students of our role models. Being a student can sometimes encapsulate us, but what’s often forgotten is our ability to teach back our knowledge.

Sydney Boys High is a place where everybody has a different passion, everybody has different skills and everybody has a different array of knowledge. Any individual may be somewhat skilled or knowledgeable on their own, but combined, those abilities are immeasurable. This magazine aims to fill a void at school. The void of student teaching.

The astute editors of this magazine recognised the huge plethora of insight available, and have harnessed it to create an ongoing medium where High boys can express themselves freely. This is a magazine where we can teach back the ideas, the work, the art and more that we’ve created. No-one should feel embarrassed or ashamed of their work here, because we all recognise the value of our fellow High boy’s ideas and effort.

Too many great pieces go unread, too many great artworks go unseen and too many great ideas go unconsidered. Hopefully, we’ve developed a platform where that unfortunate fact is addressed. It doesn’t matter if someone’s in Year 7 or Year 12, what matters is the effort and remarkable collaboration students throughout the school showed in this pursuit. Even in the testing, marketing and development phases of the magazine. The whole of the school has come together and acted as an amazing uniform, streamlined body to create this. Not one teacher touched this. At all. This is a completely student-led initiative, with one goal in mind: to transfer the power of the media to the expressive, creative and proud student. And now, the expressive, creative and proud teacher. Wow.

Enjoy!

And now, the expressive, creative and proud teacher. Wow.

Enjoy!

posts.title: Clubs and Student Run Organisations (SRO's)
posts.markdown: In addition to sports as a co-curricular aspect of High School, smaller clubs and organisations are available for students of any year to participate in. Lunch time meetings for teacher run clubs such as People Animal Welfare (PAWS) and Social Justice (SJS) give students an opportunity to immerse themselves in current affairs. SBHS has also recently introduced Student Run Organisations (SRO’s), featuring groups that focus on Card Magic and Anime for example, that give students a chance to indulge and meet others with similar interests.
posts.html: In addition to sports as a co-curricular aspect of High School, smaller clubs and organisations are available for students of any year to participate in. Lunch time meetings for teacher run clubs such as People Animal Welfare (PAWS) and Social Justice (SJS) give students an opportunity to immerse themselves in current affairs. SBHS has also recently introduced Student Run Organisations (SRO’s), featuring groups that focus on Card Magic and Anime for example, that give students a chance to indulge and meet others with similar interests.

posts.title: Japanese Animations Aaron.M and Christian.L
Apple’s New IPhone!!!!!
posts.markdown:
# The IPhone 7, Apple’s new product has received very low ratings on eBay but still has had an insane amount of purchases.

All the newest features of this phone are that it is bigger, thinner, it can hold more space and it’s waterproof.

“Apple haven’t been coming up with very innovative products since the IPad….’ Quotes a non-impressed customer.

Although some people are aboard the Apple hype train, lots of people aren’t so sure and have began to look what the difference is between these different costly products.

The current price of the IPhone 7 is $10000 which is out of the price range of most people and also is the size of an IPad mini which needs to held with two hands and when dropped, cracks appear instantaneously. With the “new” “smart keyboard” which costs an extra $1000 it becomes a clear copy of the new windows surface pro 5.

It even has apple watch integration but let’s be honest. No one will waste $1000 on a watch which is like your phone but with a smaller screen. Apple also seemed to have upped the sound level on their microphone as now siri cant hear normal  talking and someone has to look like an idiot and yell at their phone. These facts can clearly show why you would ever buy the IPhone 7 we rate it 10/10.
posts.html:

All the newest features of this phone are that it is bigger, thinner, it can hold more space and it’s waterproof.

With the “new” “smart keyboard” which costs an extra $1000 it becomes a clear copy of the new windows surface pro 5.

It even has apple watch integration but let’s be honest. No one will waste $1000 on a watch which is like your phone but with a smaller screen. Apple also seemed to have upped the sound level on their microphone as now siri cant hear normal  talking and someone has to look like an idiot and yell at their phone. These facts can clearly show why you would ever buy the IPhone 7 we rate it 10/10.

posts.title: NSW Government’s Light Rail Cost Blow-Out
posts.markdown: I am an avid political watcher. I just want to add my personal view on the SE light-rail project. I understand the crucial need for a fast frequent transport service connecting the CBD and the South East. But what I don’t get is the 1 billion dollar price tag for this project. Cities all over the world can build light rail projects with 100 million or less, including Melbourne. Sure enough, they might not have the glitz and glamour of this proposal but they still carry an almost equivalent number of passengers an hour. The big reasons as to why the SE light rail is costing taxpayers so much money are because of the plans to have battery powered light rail cars in the city part and to have one of the longest, if not, the longest tram cars in the world. It is also important to note that the ones who are managing this tram line and the trams themselves have had numerous allegations and court proceedings over rorts and other financial matters in many developed countries in the world. So when you take into account all of this info, the state Government’s decision to go ahead with this project is questionable. And never forget the pain, inconvenience and noise this project will bring to the densest parts of our metropolis for a staggering 5 years! If I was the premier of this state or at least the transport minister of NSW, I would consider one of the following options for moving South-Eastern Sydneysiders or indeed Sydneysiders as a whole: 1. a) Build a cheap, yet efficient high-frequency light rail network which is built quickly and is hassle free and reliable ( Before the stupid decision to replace tram lines with bus routes, Sydney had the largest tram network in the world. It was also the most patronised transportation system in the golden days of the first half of the 20th century. So light rail is proven to work on our home soil!) 2. b) Build a highly capable train network which will easily last for generations into the future (For the past 3 decades NSW is building some of the most expensive train lines in the world whereas other parts of the world can build them for way less than 1 billion dollars. For example the entire Rouse Hill to Chatswood line cost a whopping 10 billion dollars plus. As for comparison, the world’s longest rail tunnel in the Swiss Alps is 100 km long-that’s like building a tunnel from the city to Katoomba-and yet it costs less than 8 billion Australian dollars!) 3. c) Even better, to avoid the pain of building expensive transport networks, why don’t we just change zoning in our city so that instead of commuting to the CBD or ‘hub cities’, we can just take a walk down the road to have high quality schools, tertiary institutions, hospitals, shops, parks, homes, factories and almost everything you can imagine! ( Other cities do this and save billions of dollars and the Greens should really be arguing for this to occur so that more of us will vote for them) So there you have it! Any of these three plans are cheap, reliable and quick to build! *Daniel Bounitch (9E)*
posts.html:
I am an avid political watcher. I just want to add my personal view on the SE light-rail project.

I understand the crucial need for a fast frequent transport service connecting the CBD and the South East. But what I don’t get is the 1 billion dollar price tag for this project. Cities all over the world can build light rail projects with 100 million or less, including Melbourne. Sure enough, they might not have the glitz and glamour of this proposal but they still carry an almost equivalent number of passengers an hour. The big reasons as to why the SE light rail is costing taxpayers so much money are because of the plans to have battery powered light rail cars in the city part and to have one of the longest, if not, the longest tram cars in the world. It is also important to note that the ones who are managing this tram line and the trams themselves have had numerous allegations and court proceedings over rorts and other financial matters in many developed countries in the world. So when you take into account all of this info, the state Government’s decision to go ahead with this project is questionable. And never forget the pain, inconvenience and noise this project will bring to the densest parts of our metropolis for a staggering 5 years!

If I was the premier of this state or at least the transport minister of NSW, I would consider one of the following options for moving South-Eastern Sydneysiders or indeed Sydneysiders as a whole:

  1. a) Build a cheap, yet efficient high-frequency light rail network which is built quickly and is hassle free and reliable ( Before the stupid decision to replace tram lines with bus routes, Sydney had the largest tram network in the world. It was also the most patronised transportation system in the golden days of the first half of the 20th century. So light rail is proven to work on our home soil!)
  2. b) Build a highly capable train network which will easily last for generations into the future (For the past 3 decades NSW is building some of the most expensive train lines in the world whereas other parts of the world can build them for way less than 1 billion dollars. For example the entire Rouse Hill to Chatswood line cost a whopping 10 billion dollars plus. As for comparison, the world’s longest rail tunnel in the Swiss Alps is 100 km long-that’s like building a tunnel from the city to Katoomba-and yet it costs less than 8 billion Australian dollars!)
  3. c) Even better, to avoid the pain of building expensive transport networks, why don’t we just change zoning in our city so that instead of commuting to the CBD or ‘hub cities’, we can just take a walk down the road to have high quality schools, tertiary institutions, hospitals, shops, parks, homes, factories and almost everything you can imagine! ( Other cities do this and save billions of dollars and the Greens should really be arguing for this to occur so that more of us will vote for them)

So there you have it! Any of these three plans are cheap, reliable and quick to build!

Daniel Bounitch (9E)

posts.title: PROPAGANDA & BIASED MEDIA
posts.markdown: It is absolutely appalling that Turkey and other NATO countries are supporting or funding ISIS either directly or indirectly. The fact that a Russian SU-24M frontline bomber was downed by the Turks after it ‘violated’ Turkish airspace is even more unjust. This action just highlights the evil, impudent regime in Turkey, one which has a lack of modesty to stand up to its crime and sincerely apologise to the Russians straightaway for the deliberate downing, instead of shaking its heads and fearfully calling an emergency NATO meeting. What is also disgraceful is the baseless evidence Turkey provided to support its claims that SU-24 entered Turkish airspace for just 17 seconds before leaving the border. Turkey also has claimed that they sent 10 warnings before downing the plane, which is impossible if we suppose that the plane was indeed in Turkey for just 17 seconds. But in fact, the plane was never within metres of the border, never crossed the border even for a second and certainly did not receive any warnings from Turkey. One of the pilots who has luckily survived the incident has now stated that the bomber did not send any warnings and that the bomber just flew in secretly from behind, meaning that the pilots did not even get to see the bomber before the downing. Remember, the Turkish bomber F-16 is no match to Russia’s SU-24, which was manufactured over 30 years ago!!! So it is quite clear that the Turks are responsible for the incident and that the Russian bomber never flew into Turkish territory. If that had been the case, the US would have immediately published GPS data of the location of the plane, but since the GPS data shows that the plane crashed 4km away from the border, the US could do nothing but incite some more propaganda, just like it did back when MH-17 crashed… And what is most disgraceful out of all, is that the US and almost every other ally has declared solidarity with the perpetrators, the Turks, instead of with Russia. (which can only be purely politically-motivated). This incident has come at the wrong time – a time when it looked like cooperation between the US allies and Russia was strengthening. It is pivotal that we condemn this incident and look at closer cooperation if both we and the US are serious about defeating ISIS sooner, rather than later. Remember, ISIS makes a lot of money on selling oil to Turkey, so it is crucial to stop these trading networks to make the job much easier. I congratulate all the many American, Russian, European, Asian and Australian media organisations who have the guts to stand up for the truth and to not get brainwashed from the propaganda being desperately made by the US and Rupert Murdoch. It is truly grateful that Australia now has newspapers, such as the Australian National Review, which are independent and are unbiased in their coverage. I suggest that you all take a copy of the Australian National Review this weekend, or go online to see the countless unbiased articles which provide further information on events in Syria, Ukraine and places all over the world. My dream is that all the major media empires will one day understand the catastrophic consequences that come when they brainwash their citizens with senseless crap and will realise the unlimited benefits in becoming truly unbiased and independent. (not like the SMH, which claims to be forever independent) It is up to all of you to realise the importance of unbiased media coverage and to take a stand for the truth. The future of media and foreign relations lie in your hands… *Daniel Bounitch (9E)*
posts.html:
It is absolutely appalling that Turkey and other NATO countries are supporting or funding ISIS either directly or indirectly. The fact that a Russian SU-24M frontline bomber was downed by the Turks after it ‘violated’ Turkish airspace is even more unjust. This action just highlights the evil, impudent regime in Turkey, one which has a lack of modesty to stand up to its crime and sincerely apologise to the Russians straightaway for the deliberate downing, instead of shaking its heads and fearfully calling an emergency NATO meeting. What is also disgraceful is the baseless evidence Turkey provided to support its claims that SU-24 entered Turkish airspace for just 17 seconds before leaving the border. Turkey also has claimed that they sent 10 warnings before downing the plane, which is impossible if we suppose that the plane was indeed in Turkey for just 17 seconds. But in fact, the plane was never within metres of the border, never crossed the border even for a second and certainly did not receive any warnings from Turkey. One of the pilots who has luckily survived the incident has now stated that the bomber did not send any warnings and that the bomber just flew in secretly from behind, meaning that the pilots did not even get to see the bomber before the downing. Remember, the Turkish bomber F-16 is no match to Russia’s SU-24, which was manufactured over 30 years ago!!! So it is quite clear that the Turks are responsible for the incident and that the Russian bomber never flew into Turkish territory. If that had been the case, the US would have immediately published GPS data of the location of the plane, but since the GPS data shows that the plane crashed 4km away from the border, the US could do nothing but incite some more propaganda, just like it did back when MH-17 crashed… And what is most disgraceful out of all, is that the US and almost every other ally has declared solidarity with the perpetrators, the Turks, instead of with Russia. (which can only be purely politically-motivated).

This incident has come at the wrong time – a time when it looked like cooperation between the US allies and Russia was strengthening. It is pivotal that we condemn this incident and look at closer cooperation if both we and the US are serious about defeating ISIS sooner, rather than later. Remember, ISIS makes a lot of money on selling oil to Turkey, so it is crucial to stop these trading networks to make the job much easier. I congratulate all the many American, Russian, European, Asian and Australian media organisations who have the guts to stand up for the truth and to not get brainwashed from the propaganda being desperately made by the US and Rupert Murdoch. It is truly grateful that Australia now has newspapers, such as the Australian National Review, which are independent and are unbiased in their coverage. I suggest that you all take a copy of the Australian National Review this weekend, or go online to see the countless unbiased articles which provide further information on events in Syria, Ukraine and places all over the world. My dream is that all the major media empires will one day understand the catastrophic consequences that come when they brainwash their citizens with senseless crap and will realise the unlimited benefits in becoming truly unbiased and independent. (not like the SMH, which claims to be forever independent)

It is up to all of you to realise the importance of unbiased media coverage and to take a stand for the truth. The future of media and foreign relations lie in your hands…

Daniel Bounitch (9E)

posts.title: Stereotypes
posts.markdown:
*Americans think they invented democracy. All British people are posh and rude.  All Australian people are drunk and stupid. All Americans are rapists and murderers. These are all stupid stereotypes that are overlooked and do not get a say in society anymore, because they make no sense and are not true. So why does the stereotype “All Muslim people are terrorists” get so much attention?*

* *

*Because people need something or someone to blame. Isn’t it much easier to blame a religion for the wars that are raging instead of admitting society and humanity are really what sparked these fights? People believe that Islamic State, after murdering so many people, are still accepted in the Muslim community, but in truth, they are despised and hated for doing bad in the name of the Islamic God, by all Muslims.*

* *

*Muslims are not bad all bad, but you may be thinking, what about ISIS? How can you say these Muslims are not bad? Because they aren’t Muslims. They may claim to be, but in truth shouting “God is All” while killing it not going to put them in heaven, and nearly every Muslim person I know or have spoken to can agree, ISIS are not Muslims, and they will rot in hell.*

* *

*And all of this is written from the perspective of a Christian person. I believe in accepting all people just as Jesus Christ says to, and even though I don’t believe in Islam, this is not a valid reason for me to hate Muslims. Just like not being religious is not a valid reason to hate religion. Just like not being American is not a valid reason to hate Obama. Just like not being in Ms. Jollies class is not a valid reason to hate Ms. Jollie.*

* *

*So I will end on this note,*

*If all of these dumb, untrue stereotypes have passed through without defining society, why does one, stupid stereotype define the way the world thinks?*

* *

*<u>Keenen Roshan 7S</u>*
posts.html:
Americans think they invented democracy. All British people are posh and rude.  All Australian people are drunk and stupid. All Americans are rapists and murderers. These are all stupid stereotypes that are overlooked and do not get a say in society anymore, because they make no sense and are not true. So why does the stereotype “All Muslim people are terrorists” get so much attention?

 

Because people need something or someone to blame. Isn’t it much easier to blame a religion for the wars that are raging instead of admitting society and humanity are really what sparked these fights? People believe that Islamic State, after murdering so many people, are still accepted in the Muslim community, but in truth, they are despised and hated for doing bad in the name of the Islamic God, by all Muslims.

 

Muslims are not bad all bad, but you may be thinking, what about ISIS? How can you say these Muslims are not bad? Because they aren’t Muslims. They may claim to be, but in truth shouting “God is All” while killing it not going to put them in heaven, and nearly every Muslim person I know or have spoken to can agree, ISIS are not Muslims, and they will rot in hell.

 

And all of this is written from the perspective of a Christian person. I believe in accepting all people just as Jesus Christ says to, and even though I don’t believe in Islam, this is not a valid reason for me to hate Muslims. Just like not being religious is not a valid reason to hate religion. Just like not being American is not a valid reason to hate Obama. Just like not being in Ms. Jollies class is not a valid reason to hate Ms. Jollie.

 

So I will end on this note,

If all of these dumb, untrue stereotypes have passed through without defining society, why does one, stupid stereotype define the way the world thinks?

 

Keenen Roshan 7S

posts.title: How I would fix Sydney’s traffic
posts.markdown:
I travelled to New York recently. Manhattan is a large island, approximately 21 kilometres long or over 250 blocks (admittedly short ones) from the Bronx to the Financial District. I found myself right at the top of the island on one tourist outing, and as an avid public transport enthusiast, I was working out the best way to get back to midtown/downtown.

The Subway was the clear winner, but I was near a bus station and I was curious about the merits of New York City buses. So I did some research and, according to the MTA’s website, two Subway trains would take me 51 minutes to scale the island, including walking time. Not bad.

Two buses (on virtually direct routes) would have taken me 3 hours and 11 minutes. Ouch. Keep in mind this is roughly the distance from Sydney’s CBD to Bankstown, which takes less than an hour and a half on buses in peak hour.

The traffic in New York City is up there with the worst in the world. If it weren’t for such an extensive and (for the most part) reliable underground system, the city would probably implode with the pressure of such great population density.

In Sydney, 59% of commuters drive to work every day. In NYC, that figure is down at 28%. Even then, the major roadways simply don’t flow most of the time.

As Sydney becomes more like New York in housing, culture and economy, since my trip I’ve noticed that it’s also becoming more like it in terms of road congestion. This is bad.

So the key to beating traffic absolutely lies in getting people onto public transport and out of their cars. The New York Subway is so good because there’s lots **of** it, but NYC’s roads are so bad because there’s lots **on** it.

Here’s what I would do:

- Invest more in public transport and less in roads. New York has 34 Subway lines, Sydney has 17 (including Olympic Park and Cronulla offshoots). More trains, buses, train lines, bus lanes, light rail, ferries at regular intervals in as many places as possible. Close the blackspots on the Northern Beaches and elsewhere. Make it faster and easier to get on a train or bus. Play people’s incentives by expanding the whole system.

 

- Ban all private vehicles in the CBD all the time. Accept buses, cyclists, taxis and government delivery vehicles only. London has a congestion tax, but I think that’s regressive and unfair. If a rich person wants a fast route into the CBD, they can catch a taxi. The CBD is the centre of the daily commute and cannot practically entertain all of the cars it does at the moment. Plus, this solution would turn the city beautifully cosmopolitan. Pitt Street mall on every street.

The second solution simply must be used in conjunction with the first, but the benefit to the economy from quicker commute times will offset and actually improve initial investments for the NSW Government. I want the trains of New York City with the roads of a country town, all in Sydney.

I can add so much more detail to this article, but I thought it best to be brief. So if you don’t want a 3-hour trip to Bankstown, or do, I’d love to chat/answer questions.

Also read this he’s more eloquent than I am: [http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/should-we-ban-cars-from-melbournes-cbd-20150413-1mjuvr.html](http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/should-we-ban-cars-from-melbournes-cbd-20150413-1mjuvr.html)

By Hugh Bartley

posts.title: How Malcolm Can Control the Nutjobs
posts.markdown:
Kevin Rudd may be a flawed man, but he’s certainly a politically astute one. Which is why, earlier this month, people took notice when he appeared on *The Project* to say: “Malcolm’s got his own challenges. He’s gotta deal with the lunar right of his party, and there are some serious nutjobs there. We all know that.”

Setting aside the predictably flowery language, Rudd’s statement reflects what all of us are anticipating over the next few years. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull is obviously a fine leader and a skilful politician, but he bears the cross of political awkwardness, as most centrists do in the two-party system.

Mr 69% (as dubbed by the Herald) has the mandate of the public to do most things he reasonably wants. But the obvious hypocrisy of changing leaders and the emotions attached to the Abbott era caused a stir. Some in the party think Turnbull to be rash and overconfident. Labor thinks him to be a sell-out.

Particularly, rumours are circulating about Canberra’s nutjobs causing Turnbull some issues as he has settled into his new office. This is the same group of people who voted for Kevin Andrews as deputy leader in the recent spill.

The faction to be concerned with is a sizeable minority with sizeable power. Cory Bernardi, Kevin Andrews, Warren Truss and Eric Abetz are the biggest names floated around. For these men, “nutjob” really is an appropriate term.

Malcolm Turnbull has long described himself as a “conviction politician” and we know from past experience that he’s got a teensy bit of a leftie conviction. Well, more than a teensy bit. He proved this by crossing the floor on the ETS in 2010, amongst other acts.

Conservative MPs say that he promised to keep Direct Action, the ridiculous marriage equality plebiscite, and the Murray Darling Basin policy the same as they were under Abbott. Anthony Albanese called it selling out to become leader. Turnbull called it losing the battle to win the war. Well, inside his head at least.

But I don’t think good ol’ Malcolm is going to give up that easily. Certainly he’s passionate about his progressive solutions, as everyone around him has pleaded for years, but how can he get them through the Coalition caucus in this term or the next?

- Erode affiliations and heal the stubbornness of the Abbott past.
- Good rhetoric. Reframe debate and change the imperatives.
- Dirty work. Deals, cash-flow and blindsiding anyone that requires it.
- Jules and Scotty. Bishop and Morrison are shiny, fresh tools to use effectively.
- Mr 69% needs to keep that number up or he’s got a war on two fronts.

In my mind, those five will ensure he is able to fulfil the expectations of the swinging population, but it’ll take a while and involves a whole lot of sacrifices.

Even so, how sad a day it is when the nutjobs of politics are holding us back as a nation. Maybe we should at least *think* about Labor here. Most of their nutjobs went and joined the Greens, despite what Kevin Rudd is still salty about.

By Hugh Bartley
posts.html:

posts.title: Poems of the Century: The Peacock
posts.markdown:
When you go inside your city zoo,                                                              Then alas, a storm did rise

You should remember what you should do,                                             As if Zeus was angry at the peacock’s pride,

To visit the most pretty of all,                                                                     And a lightning bolt fell towards the ground,

The peacock will no doubt enthral,                                                            It came for the bird like a hungry hound.

 

Rumour has it the peacock is odd,                                                            But the peacock with all its vanity, it did boast,

In a good way, (it was made by the Gods)                                               As if saying ‘am I not better than most?

Venus, yes her. She gave it its looks,                                                        This lightning bolt, it will not defeat me,

The ones better than any bird in the books,                                           For my beauty around me, it will protect me!’

 

The peacock, its feathers and its mane,                                                 It was despairing, to see the peacock fall,

And its extreme ego will make you insane,                                           Your Highness, once great, was now to crawl,

As it prances and dances and enchants everything,                            In anguish and shame, of its hideous looks,

The peacock, yes, it is dressed just like a king.                                     That was uglier than any bird of the books,

 

Heaven looks down on its beautiful plumage,                                    I stared at the bird, that was once exalted,

A sight never seen, from age to age,                                                    But now, my enchantment had now faltered,

I was there at its cage, and stared with the awe,                               For if you cannot humble yourself,

That comes to you when you see waves on the shore,                    The Gods, they will reduce you to an ugly little shell.

 

I stood there watching, as if all the time in the world,                     Don’t let your vanity and pride prevail,

Had stopped in its place, at this wonderful bird,                               Don’t exalt yourself, for a fire of hail,

With all its beauty and vanity, it stood in its glory,                           Will come to you at the peak of your boast,

As if it was supreme with immortality,                                                And bring you down to some sand on the coast.

 

Caleb Chang

posts.title: Descent
posts.markdown:
I look around,

Seeing nothing.  
 Only blurs of movement,  
 Muted by shades of despair.  
 Bound to a stake of thorns,  
 Each wilted petal like stabbing death.

Arms shackled over hanging head

Like a lifeless puppet  
 I drop.

A burdened anchor plunging into sinking blackness.

The darkness wraps itself around me,  
 Like a curtain wringing the light out.  
 There I lie,  
 On beds of sleepless water.  
 Wanting to self-destruct  
 As burning waves of damning scorn  
 Echoing with self-pity  
 Ravage me of my will to live.  
 Leaving behind its calling card of tears.

I wander,  
 my haunted house  
 Searching for old photos among fresh ashes  
 Stumbling on candles I drop.  
 A prisoner in an empty cell  
 Chained to harbouring sorrow.  
 My appetite starved by grief  
 Choked by the quicksands of melancholy.

Mirrors shatter,

Jaded with sympathy,

Cascade like hungry guillotine.  
 Fighting,  
 I fly like a bird through the night  
 On clipped wings of brilliant orange,  
 I fall.

By Author Unknown.
posts.html:
I look around,

Seeing nothing.
Only blurs of movement,
Muted by shades of despair.
Bound to a stake of thorns,
Each wilted petal like stabbing death.

Arms shackled over hanging head

Like a lifeless puppet
I drop.

A burdened anchor plunging into sinking blackness.

The darkness wraps itself around me,
Like a curtain wringing the light out.
There I lie,
On beds of sleepless water.
Wanting to self-destruct
As burning waves of damning scorn
Echoing with self-pity
Ravage me of my will to live.
Leaving behind its calling card of tears.

I wander,
my haunted house
Searching for old photos among fresh ashes
Stumbling on candles I drop.
A prisoner in an empty cell
Chained to harbouring sorrow.
My appetite starved by grief
Choked by the quicksands of melancholy.

Mirrors shatter,

Jaded with sympathy,

Cascade like hungry guillotine.
Fighting,
I fly like a bird through the night
On clipped wings of brilliant orange,
I fall.

By Author Unknown.

posts.title: A Typical Aussie Summer
posts.markdown:
Feet scorch on the concrete

Blisters, Bindies burn

Santa in a singlet

Christmas bugs return

 

Air-Conditioning always powered

Crickets play their song

Lying alone in the dying heat

Awake, all night long

 

The beach always seems filled

The water crystal clear

Old men in their speedos

Let’s Crack open a Beer

 

Mozzies leave their red marks

Somewhere obviously seen

Bugs are flying everywhere

Someone get the Mortein

 

Maccas runs for Thickshakes

Bunnings BBQ

Zooper Doopers leave their scars

And thongs are worn, no shoes

 

Water fights with the hoses

Water Balloons are filled

Cold showers, Ice Bath

Burgers always grilled

 

We’ve never seen the snow

But we’re happy with the sun

We’ve grown to love the burning heat

Cause we’re the lucky ones

By WIlliam Winter

posts.title: Climate Change: A Very Serious Issue
posts.markdown:
In wake of the 2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Paris [COP21], it is evident that the issue of climate change is now more important than ever, and with greenhouse gas emissions rising every day, it is paramount that a resolution is found for this problem.

Coined as “Action Day”, the conference seeks to ‘achieve a legally binding and universal agreement on climate, from all the nations of the world.’ However, the controversial topic remains; will a mere conference solve one of the biggest problems humanity as ever faced? A prime example occurred in 2009, with the holding of a similar Climate Change Conference in Copenhagen [COP15]. What emerged from that conference was a bunch of international delegates who had done little to nothing to mitigate the severity of global warming, with international press calling climate talks in ‘serious disarray’. And so they have done it again but this time in 2015, inviting international delegations from all over the world and saying, ‘this is the day we change’, only this time it’s legally binding.

See, my friends and I used to say the exact same phrase after receiving a sub-par mark in an exam; ‘I’m going to change this’, ‘I’m going to change that’. But even so, the next assessment came and we were greeted with yet another sub-par mark. Only the difference between this and Paris is that our changes to our study habits weren’t legally binding, and we quickly returned to our inherent habits of procrastination and loafing around. We as students only changed when we stopped talking about how motivated we are and instead bent our heads over and started writing our next essay or doing more practise questions, and that reflected in our marks after we received them.

So it all comes down to the fact whether if politicians and governments are willing to knuckle down on greenhouse gas emissions, pollution and other causes of global warming, and provide enough funding to find a renewable and sustainable energy source by halfway through the century. One thing I know for sure is that it can be done. There was a time around five or six decades ago when the Space Race has just begun. NASA received funding equivalent to 4% of the national budget, and we put the first man on the moon within three years. This shows that we as humans are not lacking in our ability, but we are lacking in our will. If people around the world put aside their greed for profit and production, we would be able to live in a world much cleaner than it currently is. But the issue remains, are people willing to abandon their greed for the greater good? Or will governments have to force people to do so?

But already, the press has hailed the Paris climate talks as ‘yielding a first draft amidst air of optimism’. So it might be a good sign after all, but we should also be thankful that these countries all over the world are willing to come together as one and solve a problem that we created as one. Even if nothing results from this conference, it is satisfying to know that countries around the world want something to come out.
posts.html:
In wake of the 2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Paris [COP21], it is evident that the issue of climate change is now more important than ever, and with greenhouse gas emissions rising every day, it is paramount that a resolution is found for this problem.

Coined as “Action Day”, the conference seeks to ‘achieve a legally binding and universal agreement on climate, from all the nations of the world.’ However, the controversial topic remains; will a mere conference solve one of the biggest problems humanity as ever faced? A prime example occurred in 2009, with the holding of a similar Climate Change Conference in Copenhagen [COP15]. What emerged from that conference was a bunch of international delegates who had done little to nothing to mitigate the severity of global warming, with international press calling climate talks in ‘serious disarray’. And so they have done it again but this time in 2015, inviting international delegations from all over the world and saying, ‘this is the day we change’, only this time it’s legally binding.

See, my friends and I used to say the exact same phrase after receiving a sub-par mark in an exam; ‘I’m going to change this’, ‘I’m going to change that’. But even so, the next assessment came and we were greeted with yet another sub-par mark. Only the difference between this and Paris is that our changes to our study habits weren’t legally binding, and we quickly returned to our inherent habits of procrastination and loafing around. We as students only changed when we stopped talking about how motivated we are and instead bent our heads over and started writing our next essay or doing more practise questions, and that reflected in our marks after we received them.

So it all comes down to the fact whether if politicians and governments are willing to knuckle down on greenhouse gas emissions, pollution and other causes of global warming, and provide enough funding to find a renewable and sustainable energy source by halfway through the century. One thing I know for sure is that it can be done. There was a time around five or six decades ago when the Space Race has just begun. NASA received funding equivalent to 4% of the national budget, and we put the first man on the moon within three years. This shows that we as humans are not lacking in our ability, but we are lacking in our will. If people around the world put aside their greed for profit and production, we would be able to live in a world much cleaner than it currently is. But the issue remains, are people willing to abandon their greed for the greater good? Or will governments have to force people to do so?

But already, the press has hailed the Paris climate talks as ‘yielding a first draft amidst air of optimism’. So it might be a good sign after all, but we should also be thankful that these countries all over the world are willing to come together as one and solve a problem that we created as one. Even if nothing results from this conference, it is satisfying to know that countries around the world want something to come out.
